question:
## Problem 1
Draw mechanisms for this reaction and explain why this particular product is formed.
<!-- Media -->
`COS(=O)(=O)CCSCCS(=O)(=O)OC.C=CS(=O)(=O)OC.CCO.CO[SiH3]`
answer:
## Suggested solution
The first step must be a conjugate addition but will it be \( {\mathrm{H}}_{2}\mathrm{\;S} \) or the \( {\mathrm{{HS}}}^{ - } \) anion that does the job? The base present is \( \mathrm{{NaOAc}}\left( {\mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}}}ight. \) about 5 ) while \( {\mathrm{H}}_{2}\mathrm{\;S} \) has a \( \mathrm{p}{K}_{\mathrm{a}} \) of 7.0 so that very little of it is ionized. We should use neutral \( {\mathrm{H}}_{2}\mathrm{\;S} \) .
<!-- Media -->
`CC(CCCC[SiH3])(OC)OC.CO[C@@H](/C(=C(/CS(=O)(=O)N=[N+]=[N-])\[R11])/OC)[Y19].COS(=O)(=O)CC[Si](C)(C)C`

question:
## Problem 3
Segest reasons for the different outcomes of the following reactions (your answer must, of Then include a mechanism for each reaction).
<!-- Media -->
`CC(=O)CC(C)(C)N.CC(=CC(C)O)C.CC(=CC(=O)C)C.CC.CC.CC.CN.COS(=O)(=O)O.O`
answer: ## Suggested solution\nThe Michael acceptor is a conjugated ketone that is able to do either direct or conjugate addition. \( 1 - x \) ines are softer nucleophiles able to add reversibly and more likely to give conjugate addition by thermodynamic control. \( {\mathrm{{LiAlH}}}_{4} \) is very hard and completely irreversible so it gives direct addition - kinetic control. If you drew a full mechanism for each reaction, your answer is better than 2023.

question:
## Problem 4
Addition of dimethylamine to the unsaturated ester A could give either product B or C. Draw mechanisms for both reactions and show how you would distinguish them spectroscopically.
<!-- Media -->
`C=C(CN(C)C)C(=O)OC.C=C(C)C(=O)N([2H])N(C)C.C=C(C)C(=O)OC.CN(C)N[2H].CN(C)N[2H].[U].[U]`
answer:
## Suggested solution
The mechanisms are standard and this is an enone that really might do either. Product B is the result of direct addition followed by loss of a leaving group - a likely reaction as amines attack saturated esters in this way. This reaction is fully treated in Chapter 12.
<!-- Media -->
`C=C(C)C(CCN(C)C)(N(C)C)OC.C=C(C)C(N(C)C)(N(C)C)OC.C=C(C)C(CCN(C)C)(N(C)C)OC.[H][H].[H][H]`

question:
## Problem 5
Suggest mechanisms for the following reactions.
<!-- Media -->
`COC1=CC=C(C=C1)C23CCC(=O)CC2N(CC3)S(=O)(=O)C.CNCCC1(C=CC(=O)CC1)C2=CC=C(C=C2)OC.CC(=O)OCCN(Cl)Cl.CCOC(=O)C.C=CS(=O)(=O)Cl.CCOC(=O)C.[F-].[Na+]`
answer:
## Suggested solution
The nitro group is one of the best activating groups for conjugate addition as it almost never gives direct addition. Even the weakly nucleophilic acetate ion will react as the nitro-stabilized anion is very stable indeed.
<!-- Media -->
`CC(=O)OCC(COC(=O)C)(N1CCOCC1)[R12]([H])([H])OC(=O)C.CC(=O)OCCOC(=O)C.CC(=O)OCCO[R13](=O)C`

question:
## Problem 6
Predict the product of these reactions.
<!-- Media -->
`COC1=CC=C(/C=C/S(=O)(=O)OC)C=C1S(=O)(=O)C.C1CCC2(C1)C=CC(=O)CC2.CCN(C[X])S(=O)(=O)C.COS(=O)(=O)C.[K+].[OH-]`
answer: ## Suggested solution\nBoth reactions involve addition of organometallic compounds to unsaturated carbonyl compounds. The key difference is in the metal. With \( \mathrm{{Cu}}\left( \mathrm{I}\right) \) as catalyst,the Grignard reagent will give conjugate addition in the first example but MeLi will give direct addition in the second.

question:
## Problem 7
Two routes are proposed for the preparation of this amino-alcohol. Which do you think is more likely to succeed and why?
<!-- Media -->
`C1CCN(CC1)CCCO.C1CCN(CC1)CCCO.C1CC[NH2+]CC1.C1CC[NH2+]CC1.C(=[N-])OO.C(=[N-])OO.C(=[N-])=O.C(=[N-])=O.[Li+].[Li+]`
answer:
## Suggested solution
Addition of the amine to either an unsaturated aldehyde or ester gives a compound that car reduced to the amino-alcohol. Which is more likely to give conjugate addition? As explained in chapter (p. 236) the ester is better.
<!-- Media -->
`C1CCN(CC1)CCCO.CNC(=O)CCN1CCCCC1.C1CCNCC1.CS(=O)(=O)C=C=S.C(=O)(N)[S-].[K+]`

question:
## Problem 8
How would you prepare these compounds by conjugate addition?
<!-- Media -->
`C1=CC=C(C=C1)CSC2CCC(=O)C2.CN(C)CCOCCC#N`
answer:
## Suggested solution
All you need to do is to identify the 1,3-relationship between the nucleophile and the anion-stability group. Alternatively, you might try to spot the Michael acceptor (shown in a frame on the diagram inside the molecule you're trying to make. The nucleophiles are heteroatoms and easy to spot.
<!-- Media -->
`CN(C)CCO[C@@H]1CC[C@@]2(CO2)[C@H]1I.C=CC#C.C#CC#C.C#CC#C.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC.C#CC`

question:
## Problem 9
How might this compound be made using a conjugate addition as one of the steps? You might find it helpful to consider the preparation of tertiary alcohols as described in Chapter 9 and also to refer back to Problem 1 in this chapter.
<!-- Media -->
`CC(C)(CCN(CCC(C)(C)O)NC)O`
answer:
## Suggested solution
We need carbonyl groups to do conjugate addition so the tertiary alcohols will have to be made from them. In Chapter 9 (p. 222) we saw how to make such tertiary alcohols from esters and organometallic compounds and in Problem 1 of this set we saw how to do double conjugate additions on unsaturated esters - all the pieces fit together.
<!-- Media -->
`CC(C)(CCN(CCC(C)(C)O)S(=O)(=O)C)O.CN(CCS(=O)(=O)F)CCS(=O)(=O)F.C=CS(=O)(=O)F.CN(C)S(=O)(=O)F.CN(C)S(=O)(=O)F`

question:
## Problem 10
Ahen we discussed reduction of cyclopentenone to cyclopentanol, we suggested that ::! Jugate addition of borohydride must occur before direct addition of borohydride; in other - TCS, this scheme must be followed:
<!-- Media -->
`C1CCC(=O)C1`
answer:
## Suggested solution
the alternative scheme would be to reduce the ketone first and the alkene second.
<!-- Media -->
`C1=CC(=O)CC1`

question:
## Problem 11
Suggest a mechanism for this reaction. Why does conjugate addition occur rather than direct addition? Why is the product shown as a cation? If it is indeed a salt, what is the anion?
<!-- Media -->
`C[Si](C)(C)OC1=CC(CCC1)P(P)P.C1C=CC(=O)CC1.C[Si](C)(C)Cl.CP(P)P`
answer:
## Suggested solution
The phosphine is a soft reversible nucleophile and is good at conjugate addition while unsaturated ketones are good at both types of reaction. On balance, conjugate addition wins. The intermediate enolate is trapped by silicon - an excellent electrophile for oxygen. The product is indeed a cation. The nucleophile was neutral and has lost electrons in the addition step. The counterion is chloride as all the atoms in the reagents are incorporated into the product.
<!-- Media -->
`C[Si](C)(C)CC12CCCC(CC1)(C2)C[Si](C)(C)Cl.[Cl-].[Ti+2]`

question:
## Problem 12
How, by choice of reagent, would you make this reaction give the direct addition product (route A)? How would you make it give the conjugate addition product (route B)?
<!-- Media -->
`CCCCC(C)CC(=O)C.CCCCC(C)(/C=C/C)O.CC(=O)/C=C/COC(F)(F)F.CC(F)(F)F`
answer:
## Suggested solution
The added fragment is obviously a butyl group and the nucleophile should be BuLi, BuMgBr, or some other organometallic reagent. The two we have mentioned prefer direct addition and we shall have to add \( \mathrm{{Cu}}\left( \mathrm{I}ight) \) to get conjugate addition.
<!-- Media -->
`CCCCC(C)(C=CC)O.[CH3-]`
